title: Stalker posts champagne celebration snaps as early jail release angers victims
text:

A stalker has been pictured raising a glass of champagne and relaxing at home after serving just a quarter of her one-year sentence behind bars.

Jill Sharp's celebrations have angered her victims, who say the 33-year-old has shown a "total lack of remorse" while flaunting her freedom in Facebook posts.

One snap shows Rangers fan Sharp, of Airdrie, North Lanarkshire, grinning widely on a sofa with her partner Craig Hale while they are dressed in matching pyjamas.

Their hands are clasped as they clutch glasses of Moët & Chandon champagne are surrounded by balloons reading "Welcome home" and "#Done", the Daily Record reports.

An undated photo posted after her early release shows her smiling in a hot tub while raising a glass of Veuve Clicquot on a previous holiday.

(Image: Daily Record)

A friend commented: "You will be back there before you know it.

Sharp replied with a plane emoji, writing: "You know me only too well lol... The countdown is on!"

Sharp was released from jail after serving just three months of her one-year term for stalking two former friends, creating fake social media profiles while tormenting them.

When she was sentenced at Livingston Sheriff Court in July, she wept in the dock and a judge blasted her for her "disgraceful and wicked” terror campaign against Maggie Paton, 58, and her husband Steve.

Sharp sent emails to the couple’s workplaces with false claims they were involved in criminal activity, including dealing drugs to kids.

(Image: Daily Record)

Mr Paton, 60, hit out at Sharp following her release, telling the Daily Record: “There is a total lack of remorse for what she put us through.

This obsession she has with champagne is sad but we won’t be intimidated by her.

“It seems ridiculous that Sharp was sentenced to 12 months but only served three and is out before Christmas.

“But the whole world now knows what she did after she admitted it in court.

"She is the type to just keep squirming and denying everything but even her friends and family know she is an obsessive stalker and fantasist.

(Image: Daily Record)

“She may have got out of jail early but her reputation has been destroyed forever by what she did to us.

"She is a laughing stock at Ibrox and you would have to be off your head to believe she is innocent after all the details emerged in court.”

After her release from jail Sharp reactivated her Facebook account and posted the snaps of her and Hale celebrating with champagne.

The couple both still live with their parents.

In one photo, they are seen wearing matching Rangers pyjamas.

But fans have made it clear they are not welcome at old haunts such as the well-known Rangers pub the Louden Tavern.

One wrote on Twitter : “All joking aside, disgraceful those two maniacs still think it’s acceptable to post the stuff they do.

“Welcome Home balloons, the lot, knowing the fact it’ll get a reaction and she will be bold enough to flaunt herself in the Louden the next home game.”

In the comments under Sharp's Facebook photos, her friends wrote "welcome back" and one even joked "where did u disappear to", which Sharp responded to with a laughing emoji.

One friend wrote: "Good to see you with the rangers top back on."

Sharp replied: "Thank you very much! It sure feels good lol!"

During Sharp’s sentencing, Sheriff Douglas Kinloch said she “succeeded” in ruining the Patons’ lives, leaving them on medication and unable to work for lengthy periods.

He said he had considered calling for a psychiatric assessment of Sharp in a bid to shed light on her behaviour.

But he didn’t believe such a report could explain her “deliberate and malicious” crimes, which showed a “high degree of planning”.

In February 2017, it was reported that Sharp had stalked a man who was a complete stranger to her.

She created a fake second life using photos Graham McQuet and his fiancée Marianne Stirling had posted on social media.

Sharp copied their movements so she could be pictured in places they had visited, then posted loved-up snaps online..

She set up a fake Twitter page for her "boyfriend" and sent romantic messages between them, as well as explicit details of an imaginary sex life.

Iain Smith, defending, told the court: “She takes no pleasure in what she did. She regrets it.”
description: Rangers fan Jill Sharp, of Airdrie, North Lanarkshire, who created fake social media profiles while tormenting two former pals, is seen grinning widely on a sofa while clutching a glass of Moet with partner Craig Hale
